string-array.name: simple_que
string-array.item: What Android means?
What is Android and why it is used?
What is Android and iOS?
Is Android a phone or OS?
Where is Android mostly used?
What are the Android components?
What is iOS full form?
How many types of Android phones are there?
What are three features of Android?
What is Android life cycle?

string-array.name: simple_ans
string-array.item: An Android phone is a powerful, high-tech smartphone that runs on the Android operating system (OS) developed by Google and is used by a variety of mobile phone manufacturers.
The Android operating system is a mobile operating system that was developed by Google to be primarily used for touchscreen devices, cell phones, and tablets.
Google Android and Apple iOS are operating systems used primarily in mobile technology, such as smartphones and tablets.

Android is an OS created by Google® for use on mobile devices, such as smartphones and tablets. It is available on devices made by a variety of manufacturers, giving you more choices of device style and pricing.

Even though in mature markets user growth has stagnated, Android has continued to grow at a remarkable rate through its popularity in developing countries. In Brazil, India, Indonesia, Turkey and Vietnam, Android has over 85% market share.
The core building blocks or fundamental components of android are activities, views, intents, services, content providers, fragments and AndroidManifest. xml.

The full form of IOS is i-Phone operating system. IOS is the operating system used by Apple in their devices. The first i-Phone has been launched in 2007 and in 2022 the IOS introduced its 15th version.
There are now nearly 1,300 brands that have produced over 24,000 distinct Android devices.Google Play offers over 1 million apps for Android devices from developers all over the world.

Android devices can include still/video cameras, touchscreens, GPS, accelerometers, gyroscopes, barometers, magnetometers, dedicated gaming controls, proximity and pressure sensors, thermometer and accelerated 2D bit blits.

An Android activity goes through six major lifecycle stages or callbacks. These are: onCreate() , onStart() , onResume() , onPause() , onStop() , and onDestroy() . The system invokes each of these callbacks as an activity enters a new state.
